key_risks: Ongoing class action lawsuit alleging anti-competitive practices
Economic sensitivity to housing market, consumer spending, and weather conditions
Supply chain vulnerabilities due to reliance on manufacturers
Competition from other distributors and direct-to-consumer sales channels
controversies: Consolidated class action lawsuit filed in 2011 involving major manufacturers
Potential vertical supply chain agreements under antitrust scrutiny
environmental_issues: Uptick in pool-related chemical incidents, including public pool mishaps and residential fires
social_issues: Diversity and inclusion efforts, with a focus on occupational health and safety
Enforcement of policies against human trafficking, forced labor, and child labor
governance_issues: Adherence to ethical standards, including compliance with the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act

sources.title: PoolCorp Lawsuit Enters Next Phase| Pool & Spa News
sources.snippet: The class action was originally filed in 2011 and consists of a number of lawsuits that have been consolidated. It involves two sets of plaintiffs and two sets of defendants. On the plaintiff side are pool and spa dealers and distributors called "direct purchasers" and consumers called "indirect purchasers."

sources.title: Avoiding Pool Chemical-Associated Health Events
sources.snippet: Ensure that safety equipment, such as gloves and goggles, are available. sources.title: Swimming Pool Chemical Safety: How to Handle Spills Properly
sources.snippet: Post-Spill Procedures. After cleaning up a chemical spill, it's important to follow these steps: Reporting: Document the incident and report it to the appropriate authorities if required. Restocking Supplies: Replenish any used safety supplies and ensure that spill kits are complete. Reviewing Protocols: Evaluate the response to the spill and update safety protocols and training as necessary.
